Thank you @sippingsocialite and the entire team of @thehuesociety for this special recognition of "Humanitarian Of The Year." 

I want to first thank Tahiirah and her entire team for all of the incredible work that they are doing to make our industry more inclusive.

It is individuals like her and The Hue Society that motivate and inspire me to do better and work even harder.

I am absolutely grateful for this beautiful award and I now proudly have it displayed in my office. 

Of course this recognition is an embodiment of everyone that has been a part of this journey and most importantly I make no illusions that this would not have happened without the love and support of all those around me. There have been so many people that have sacrificed themselves in order for me to live a better life and for that I want to especially thank my wife and family.

I look forward to 2023 and continuing the work that is needed to make our industry a better one.

Stay Calm; Breathe; and Keep Pushing Forward ✨️

Image Description: 

Picture 1: A colorful and beautifully designed restaurant

Picture 2: A vibrant and colorful photo of Contento's signature ceviche

You must put yourself in uncomfortable situations and do things that you often do not want to do because that is the only way growth and evolution happens. Playing it safe will do you no good and life is about the obstacle. The worst thing you can do for your older self is to look back with a bill of regret and say to yourself I should have done this or I could have done that. Remind yourself of "The Pause" and once you can get into the habit of "The Pause" you will find yourself more in control of your immediate reactions. Discipline is the core of everything in your life so instead of saying I will do it later; why not say I will get it done now. There is no reason to push things to the side because usually they will never get done. 

You were good to me 2022 but I look forward to what is to come and to the many challenges in 2023.

Stay Calm; Breathe; Keep Pushing Forward.

🌟 Incontra i giudici di 5StarWines & Wine Without Walls 2023!

Oggi presentiamo Yannick Benjamin, Co-fondatore di Beaupierre Wines & Spirits, Contento Restaurant e Wine on Wheels e parte della nostra giuria di Panel Chair!

Yannick, sommelier di base a New York, è il co-fondatore del ristorante “Contento” nell’East Harlem, aperto nel 2021. È anche co-fondatore e direttore del business development di “Wine on Wheels”, un’organizzazione che aiuta persone neo-disabili. 
Nel 2003, a seguito di un incidente stradale, Benjamin è rimasto paralizzato, ma questo non lo ha fermato dal perseguire il proprio sogno di frequentare il college e diventare sommelier. Dopo le sue esperienze iniziali presso Le Cirque, Jean-Georges, Felidia e Atelier al Ritz Carlton, Benjamin è tornato per oltre sette anni a servire vino presso Le Dû’s Wines, diventando inoltre un para-atleta. Benjamin e i suoi soci hanno aperto Contento con la filosofia e il motto “accessibile a tutti”. È uno splendido esempio di hospitality di qualità pensata con un approccio ampiamente inclusivo.

Scopri i giudici della settima edizione, visita ora il nostro sito.
******
🌟 Meet the judges of 5StarWines & Wine Without Walls 2023!

Here is Yannick Benjamin, Co-Founder of @beaupierrewinenyc, @contentonyc , and @wineonwheelsnyc and part of our Panel Chairs jury!

Benjamin, a New York City-based sommelier, is the co-founder of Contento Restaurant in East Harlem, which opened in 2021. He is also a co-founder and director of development for Wine on Wheels, an organization that helps recently disabled people. 
In 2003, a car accident left Benjamin paralyzed, but he pursued his dreams to attend college and become a sommelier. Having worked in his early years at Le Cirque, Jean-Georges, Felidia, and Atelier at the Ritz Carlton, Benjamin went back to wine service at Le Dû’s Wines for more than seven years and became an accomplished athlete. Benjamin and partners opened Contento with the ethos and tagline “accessible for all”. It is a stunning example of quality hospitality designed with a broadly inclusive approach.
On the road in Provence. A beautiful first day in Cassis with  @clossaintemagdeleine. It was magical and everything I would imagine it to be.

Merci Mr.Reynald Delille for hosting us at your home. Domaine de Terrebrune is truly a magical place and it was such an honor to spend time with you. Bandol is an incredible place and I am so happy to finally be able to explore this special terroir.

It was another incredible day in Bandol. A special thank you to both Audrey Arlon of @domainedestroisfilles and Daniel Ravier of @domaine_tempier.

I look forward to coming back!

This historic estate, situated in the l south of Aix-en-Provence, has been in the hands of four generations of the Rougier family since 1830. Thank you to the entire Rougier family for graciously hosting us at your historical estate. The wines are just mesmerizing!

A few days ago, I had the opportunity to go back and explore the legendary Châteauneuf-du-Pape appellation. We had some great visits, and I am always blown away by the massive amount of galets (big pudding stones) in this area of France. The journey will continue.

Image Description: 3 different photos with the winemakers. Photo 1 is with Brun-Avril at their domaine. Photo 2 is a photo with Isabel Ferrando showing us her winery. Photo 3 is a photo of Laurence Feraud of Pegau.

What a privilege it is to have the opportunity to be able to drive through some of the most beautiful vineyards in the world. The Northern Rhone is full of tradition and it is electrifying as ever with the hardest-working vignerons who are incredibly passionate about their craft.

Thank you to Jean Gonon, Pierre Clape, and Thierry Allemand for making time in their busy schedules.

Image Description: I have posted a few photos of myself with the producers from the Northern Rhone. All the photos are taken in their winery.

location.city_name: Domaine Christian Moreau Père et Fils

social_posts.post_text: It has become a ritual whenever I come to France to visit Chablis as it is one of my favorite places but most importantly to spend time with Christian Moreau while I am there. I have so much gratitude and I am humbled after each visit. It is such an honor to have the opportunity to spend time with such a class act. Christian Moreau is one of my favorite people and he has taught me so much throughout the years. I am truly grateful for these special moments. Thank you, Christian!

Domaine Marie de Louvoy has vineyards located in the Châtillonnais and their domaine can be found in the charming little village of Molesme. It was exciting to finally visit this young and upcoming producer making wines in the exciting terroir. They are both creating magic and this is just the beginning.

Looking back at what a glorious trip we had in France. It was an immense honor to spend time with Michéle  Aubéry-Laurent of the legendary Domaine Gramenon. A spectacular place with so much heart and soul.

Thank you to the entire team @jancisrobinson for the love and support!

We are truly grateful 🙏

Next Wednesday is ED Talks and we are so honored to present our next speaker, Yannick Benjamin, a New York City-based sommelier and co-founder of Wine on Wheels, Beaupierre Wines & Spirits, and Contento Restaurant.

Among his various accolades and media appearances (Wine Enthusiast’s Top 40 under 40, 2017 Person of the Year by New Mobility Magazine, and 2021 Sommelier/Wine Director of The Year by Wine Enthusiast Wine Star Awards, to name a few), Yannick has gained prominence for his inclusive approach to quality hospitality. 

Through Beaupierre Wines & Spirits, his wine shop, Wine on Wheels, his charitable organization of wine lovers and sommeliers, and Contento, his East Harlem restaurant, Yannick cultivates spaces of community where inclusivity, diversity, and sustainability reign king.

Join us for Yannick’s speech, “Virtue in Hospitality: Working and Living In Agreement With Nature,” where he explores how stoicism and having a daily mantra have allowed him to be prepared for everything and anything that comes his way in the hospitality industry.

EatDenver members, find full details and your free registration link through the latest member newsletter. Not an EatDenver member but want to get involved? Send us a DM!

Thank you to the beautiful city of Denver for showing me a good time. 

A special thank you to the amazing Sarah Abell and the entire team at Eat Denver for having me on stage.

Here are some of the topics that I discussed that helps me get through a busy day. 

*Live In Agreement with Nature 

*This is a gift 

*Thank you for all of the challenges that you will present to me 

*The Pause (Stay Calm); Breathe; Keep Pushing Forward 

*Dichotomy of Control 

*The Pause 

*Delay any opinions or words 

*One Mouth Two Ears 

*Stillness is the kingdom 

*No Complaining 

*You become what you give your attention to
Perfection 🙏

On my recent trip to Italy, I had the honor and privilege to visit La Stoppa, located in northwest Emilia-Romagna, but more specifically in Rivegaro.

I've always had so much love and respect for this extraordinary farm. The wines are pure and honest with so much integrity.

I also had the pleasure to spend some time with Elena Panatleoni, who continues to take this winery to new heights.

Thank you, @agricolalastoppa 😊 

Always on the search to learn new things and meet extraordinary people!

Thank you to the amazing Mateja Gravner for hosting me at her family's home. It was a dream come true to come and spend time with this extraordinary family located in the heart of Oslavia. It was also an honor to meet the legendary Josko Gravner.

This was certainly a visit that I will never forget! 

"In the hills above Gorizia, in sight of both the Julian Alps and the Adriatic, Joško Gravner’s family has made wine in the neighboring villages of Hum and Oslavia for generations. Long a part of the Austro-Hungarian empire, the Collio Goriziano/Goriška Brda has, since being razed in the First World War, been traded between Italy, Nazi Germany, Yugoslavia, and Slovenia. From 18 ha of vineyards in these contested hills planted to Ribolla Gialla and Pignolo (Gravner recently ripped up his international varieties), Gravner makes some of the most compelling and thought-provoking wines we have ever encountered." Rosenthal Wine Merchant

Thank you, Ilaria Felluga, for a beautiful afternoon tasting in Friuli-Venezia Giulia. The wines at @marcofelluga_russizsuperiore are magnificent, and it was a great honor to learn and taste with you.

🍷 Wine on Wheels is back! Join us on Sunday, September 10th, 2023, at City Winery NYC from 11am-3pm to celebrate the return of NYC's top restaurants and sommeliers.

A lot has changed since March 2020 but instead of looking back on how difficult it was, we should take a moment of gratitude that somehow we were able to navigate the storm and work according to what nature has given us. We've survived the storm, and it's time to come together and cheer each other on for making it through without forgetting those that suffered throughout this period. Our first Wine on Wheels will have a different format because it was an opportunity to start fresh on a blank canvas.

This year, we will have over 30 restaurants & retail partners represented each by their very own sommelier, and they will be pouring wines that best reflect their establiments's philosophy and  spirit. We will also have NYC's top mixologist sharing their signature cocktail and an amazing selection of food tables led by NYC's top Chefs.

👉 Get your tickets now and use the code EARLYBIRD to get 20% off (link in bio). We look forward to seeing you and sharing a glass of wine to support the disability community.

#WineOnWheels #NYC #CityWinery #FoodAndWine #Sommelier #Mixologist #NYCRestaurants #EarlyBirdDiscount

Keush was founded in 2013 by Vahe Keushguerian, and produces traditional method sparkling wines made with indigenous grape varieties. Sourced from the village of Khachik in the Vayots Dzor region. These are 100-120 year old bush vines growing at 1,750 meters above sea level, some of the highest elevation vineyards in Armenia.

Areni-1 Cave is located in Vayots Dzor, Armenia, which claims to be home to the oldest winery in the world, in operation some 6,100 years ago. Unfortunately, this archaeological site has over 150 steep steps to get in, but I am always ready for an adventure, and when I have Jahdea on my side to help me get up there the opportunity is impossible to refuse. 

I am forever grateful for Jahdea and Team Armenia 🇦🇲 who helped me get  to the cave and experience this marvel of the world.

I was exhausted when I got back to the base, but it was worth it, but it was the support and love of these special human brings that I will never forget.

We just arrived at the western side of Sicilia, and it's my first time in Trapani. I am grateful to be here with the great Filippo Bartolotta who has so much depth and knowledge when it comes to this historical island.

Image Description: Filippo is to my left and dressed in black, and I am to his right wearing a vest, grey hooded sweater, and blue jeans. We are both standing in front of an antique palmento.

A palmento is a building and the antique mechanism inside of it where wine grapes were made into juice (mosto) that eventually became wine.
Somewhere in Trapani....
Yes please!
I can't wait to come back! Thank you @winesofsicily, for a beautiful trip on the West Coast of Sicilia.

The more I see, the more I taste, and the less I know. There is so much history when it comes to Marsala, and it was a mind blowing experince to visit Cantine Pellegrino and have a better understanding of the beauty of Marsala.

A few days ago before Mount Etna erupted, I had an incredible visit with Giusepppe Russo and Dante Pasqua of @girolamorussoetna located in  Passopisciaro within the Northern Slopes of Etna. 

Absolutely stunning wines, and the terroir is breathtaking! 

Thank you to the entire team of Girolamo Russo. 

'Giuseppe Russo took over the estate in 2004, inheriting his father Girolamo’s 12 hectares on the north face of Etna near Passopisciaro right when the Etna renaissance was blossoming. At 32 years of age, Giuseppe studied in music and had a PHD in literature and knew nothing of wine except what he had absorbed from his childhood growing up in the shadows of this mighty mountain. His intention was to be a pianist, a passion that he still enjoys as a hobby today. His philosophy about making wine always takes into consideration music and composition. As is often the case on Etna where camaraderie thrives, Giuseppe turned to his neighbors and fellow winemakers for knowledge and inspiration when he took over the family property. To this day, he cites specific individuals for helping to instill his current philosophy about winemaking. Humble, reserved, and introverted, Giuseppe’s wines have become the signature of the power, energy, and uncompromising elegance that defines Etna winemaking today. -Grand Cru Selections

It was a glorious visit with the Foti family. I have always admired what this family has been able to accomplish throughout the years with such grace and persistence despite the obstacles. Mount Etna is a magical place, but it takes a lot of strength and honor to be able to work alongside this unpredictable mountain.

Salvo and Simone are two of the kindest human beings I have ever met, and it was a dream come true to be able to experience their home on Mount Etna.

"The I Vigneri project spans over 30 hectares and many producers in Etna, with the team working the vines traditionally and Salvo helping to make the wines. This estate is Salvo's personal project along with his sons Simone and Andrea." Louis/Dressner

It was a beautiful day in Vittoria as I had the amazing opportunity to learn about this special place. Thank you, @aziendaagricolacos @ariannaocchipinti, for hosting me and showing me the beauty of your wines and terroir.

Thank you to Salvino Benanti and the team for welcoming me to their historical winery. It was a magical tasting, and it gave me a real understanding of the incredible work that they are doing and why these wines are absolutely incredible. 

"Benanti is one of the most respected wineries in Sicily, and their wines from Mount Etna are some of the best in the world. The winery has been in the Benanti family for over 100 years, and they have a deep understanding of the terroir of Mount Etna. Their wines are made from 100% native grapes, and they are known for their minerality, complexity, and aging potential." -Wilson Daniels

What a perfect way to end my journey of Etna in the village of Maletto, which is in the northwest part of the mountain. I was introduced to these wines by @corkhoarder, who advised me to visit Sonia Gambino, an incredibly talented and passionate winemaker, but most importantly, a tremendous human being. This was a memorable visit @gustinellawine and one that I will  never forget. She definitely has my loyalty going forward as these wines are nothing but pure energy and umami.

When I travel, my goal is to try to explore as many places as I can. Rarely do I ever ever visit the same place twice, but I just had to with Cave Ox Restaurant. This is, in my opinion, what a perfect restaurant is all about with good food and great wine! Nestled between the vineyards and Mount Etna-Cave Ox is a hangout for local Etna winemakers and their following, which is owned and run by one of the best restaurateurs, Sandro Dibello. This is a place with so much soul, and I truly consider it one of the best restaurant experiences I ever had. 

Thank you, Sandro, and to the team of this magnificent restaurant!

I will be forever grateful for the wonderful weekend hosted by Caitlin and Andy at their wonderful home in the beautiful city of Indianapolis. Having to experience the Indy 500 one of the world's greatest sporting events was spectacular, and one that I never forget. Besides the Indy 500, we had an opportunity to taste some wonderful wines, but most importantly, to spend time with the most incredible human beings. 

I have so much admiration and love for Andy, and I am blessed to have him as a dear friend.
It was a beautiful night watching @nycfc with great friends.
It is always a special moment to host my dear friends at Beaupierre. Thank you, Reggie, for all of your help in making Beaupierre happen, and I am grateful for our 20 years of friendship ❤️

Epictetus was a Greek philosopher and was born into slavery and walked with a limp, a disability he may have had from birth, from when his leg was broken deliberately by his enslaver, or from a later medical condition

Later on in his life, he became an important philosophical voice with an impact that would inspire generations.

Frida Kahlo, a Mexican woman of color with disabilities, lived from 1907 to 1954. In 1913, when she was around 6 years old, Kahlo contracted polio, which at the time didn't have treatments and left her with physical disabilities. The virus did damage to her right leg and foot. 

At the age of 18, Frida Kahlo was injured in a bus accident, which crushed her foot and dislocated her shoulder. Her collarbone, two ribs, and one leg were broken. But the most detrimental injuries were to her spine and pelvis.

Despite these obstacles, artist Frida Kahlo continued to live life to the fullest and is remembered for her self-portraits, pain and passion, and bold, vibrant colors. She is celebrated in Mexico and around the world for her attention to Mexican and indigenous culture and by feminists for her depiction of the female experience and form.

We honor Frida Kahlo and her accomplishments during Disability Pride Month 2023.

Judy Heumann (1947-2023) Judy Heumann was an internationally recognized advocate for the rights of disabled people. At 18-months-old, Judy contracted polio in Brooklyn, New York, and began to use a wheelchair for her mobility.

Known as the “mother of the disability rights movement,” Heumann organized protests, advocated for new legislation, and served in two presidential administrations.

Franklin D. Roosevelt was diagnosed with poliomyelitis and underwent years of therapy, including hydrotherapy at Warm Springs, Georgia. Roosevelt remained paralyzed from the waist down and used a wheelchair and leg braces for mobility, which he took efforts to conceal in public for fear of judgement.

President Roosevelt directed the federal government during most of the Great Depression, implementing the New Deal in response to the worst economic crisis in American history.

text_entities.entity: annual academy of spinal cord injury professionals conference

social_posts.post_text:
I recently had the honor and privilege to speak as the Keynote Speaker in front of a large audience of health care professionals at the Amerian Spinal Cord Injury Professionals Conference in San Diego My topic was on how to work and live with virtue, which is something that I try  to do myself but admittedly fail at it on certain moments. 

There is no doubt that we can do better in the healthcare profession, but one aspect that we can greatly  improve uopn is incorporating better hospitality between the patient and healthcare professional. I am here today because of these exact relationships that I have built with these passionate professionals, and without them, I would not be here doing what I am doing, but we can always do better. The future of  healthcare is incorporating the philosophy of what great hospitality establishments practice.

Finally, to have a list of personal tenets is also incredibly helpful for growth and holding yourself accountable. As the great Aristotle  once said, "Quality is not an act but a habit." 

Here are some of my tenets and topics that I discussed:

Pause 
One Mouth, Two Ears
Say Less 
Hold back on opinions 
No judgments 
Be mysterious
Defend those who are not in the room
Stop Complaining 
Deeds, not words 
Embrace your tortue
Do hard things
Be uncomfortable and learn something new 
Discipline now, freedom later 
You can delay, but time won't 
You become what you give your attention to 
Love the fate

text_entities.entity: amerian spinal cord injury professionals conference

social_posts.post_text:
This week, I had the incredible honor and privilege to be the Keynote Speaker at The Academy of Spinal Cord Injuries Annual Conference in San Diego. As I prepared my presentation, I came across a Jerry Seinfeld interview clip about how he’s always in search of material for his next joke. The interviewer tells Seinfeld that it sounds like a tortured existence to be constantly looking for material in every daily interaction. BUT Jerry brilliantly responds, “The blessing in life is when you find the torture you are comfortable with. That’s marriage. It’s kids. It’s work. It’s exercise. Find the torture you’re comfortable with and you’ll do well. You’ve mastered that, you’ve mastered life.”
 
THIS completely resonated with me. Nothing that you truly love will ever come easy, and it shouldn’t because, as the great Ryan Holiday says, “the obstacle is the way.”
 
One of the greatest tortures in my life is Wine on Wheels. It is also one of my greatest passions.
 
Despite what the last 4 years threw at us, I never stopped fighting or believing that Wine on Wheels would happen again. And in less than 3 days, all the torture that we went through will have been worth it when we get to see you all under one roof at City Winery Hudson River NYC. 
 
We are super close to capacity, so we are closing sales in a few hours.
 
Get your tickets to support our cause now.

“The blessing in life is when you find the torture you are comfortable with. That’s marriage, it’s kids, it’s work, it’s exercise. Find the torture you’re comfortable with and you’ll do well. You’ve mastered that, you’ve mastered life.” — Jerry Seinfeld

This is the quote that I will be repeating to myself while I push myself through the five  boroughs and attempt to accomplish my 11th NYC Marathon. I recently discovered this quote by the great Jerry Seinfeld and ever since it has completely resonated with me. I have come to realize that doing the things that we love can be tortuous but at the same time it can be a blessing and this best describes the NYC Marathon. This is one of the most grueling courses and it doesn't get any easier as I get older but I have a mission and that is what will get me to Central Park because it is through that struggle where there is progress. 

If I feel some discomfort and fatigue I know that when I cross that finish line I can comfort myself by knowing that I have contributed to The Axis Project which is something near and dear to my heart. When my friend and mentor George Gallego told me that he needed my help; there was no possible way that I was going to say no even though I was reluctant to do so but NYC's disability community needs a home and The Axis Project is it. 

This will be a multidisciplinary center committed to providing high-quality services for Seniors and People with Physical Disabilities. This unique center empowers people to pursue a healthy, active lifestyle through our programs, activities, and classes. I am proud to be representing such a worthy cause and most of all I look forward to seeing you on the course.

Feel free to give me a push if you see me in a tortured state! 

Blessings and Gratitude,
Yannick

No validation is greater than receiving an email from my greatest teacher and mentor. Thank you, Brother Reynolds, for being the example of what living with virtue means. Almost 40 years later, I still think about our long conversations in your art room, and I am forever grateful for everything that you brought to my life.

On a stormy evening in New York City on October 27th, 2003, my life was forever altered. At 25, I believed I had everything figured out - a fulfilling job, progressing wine certifications, a loving network of family and friends, and, above all, good health. However, within a few hours of the car accident, I sensed its potential long-lasting impact, though I couldn't fathom the extent of its consequences.

For a long time, that moment remained a perplexing memory, its impact unclear. It wasn't until I read an interview between Stephen Colbert and Anderson Cooper that a new perspective began to take shape, allowing me to embrace the fate dealt to me.

Cooper, holding back tears, queried, "You told an interviewer that you have learned to—in your words—‘love the thing that I most wish had not happened.’ 'What punishments of God are not gifts?’ Do you really believe that?”
 
“Yes,” replied Colbert, attributing the quote to J.R.R. Tolkien, author of Lord of the Rings. “It’s a gift to exist, and with existence comes suffering. There’s no escaping that. I don’t want it to have happened. I want it to not have happened, but if you are grateful for your life—which I think is a positive thing to do, not everybody is, and I am not always but it's the most positive thing to do—then you have to be grateful for all of it. You can’t pick and choose what you're grateful for.”
 
I came to understand that pain is inseparable from progress. Embracing my circumstances took time, yet through this journey, I've traversed parts of the world I'd never have seen, encountered people I'd have never met, cherished precious moments with my family and friends, and found the love of my life in my wife.
 
Every day, I remind myself of a mantra: “Amor fati," a Latin phrase signifying "love of fate" or "love of one's fate." It encapsulates an outlook where one accepts every event in their life, including suffering and loss, as either inherently good or, at the very least, as an essential part of their journey. As I reflect on my 20th anniversary of my accident, I can think of no better way to celebrate than by participating in the NYC Marathon, all the while supporting The Axis Project.

Embrace the opportunity for daily improvement, understanding that meaningful change often unfolds incrementally. Never allow complacency to hinder your journey toward personal growth and success. Every day is a chance to be better than the day before.

Thank you, @finedininglovers, for this beautiful recognition.

In the world of philosophy, few names shine as brightly as that of Marcus Aurelius, the Roman Emperor often referred to as "The Philosopher King." His remarkable book, "Meditations," is a treasure trove of insight into Stoic philosophy and the inner workings of one of history's most influential figures.
 
This book was never intended for public consumption. It was his personal journal, and it was only after his passing that these private notes were compiled into what we now know as "Meditations." For those unfamiliar with this masterpiece, I can not recommend it highly enough.

The opening chapter of "Meditations" is a testament to the principles of Stoic philosophy. In it, Marcus Aurelius expresses his gratitude to the individuals who had a positive impact on his life. His focus is on those who instilled in him the qualities characteristic of a true Stoic.
 
So, why did I decide to run the marathon this year. The answer is simple: I needed to embrace discomfort once again. There's something truly special about having a few hours to yourself, traversing through the greatest city on earth, and reflecting on the people who've made a lasting impact in your life – much like Marcus Aurelius did in his "Meditations." And of course, the other obvious reason is to raise money and awareness for The Axis Project. 
 
I have no illusions that there will not be moments of doubt and regret during the marathon. The 59th Street Bridge has always been my three-headed monster. And while I'm already dreading that part, I've decided to approach each section of the marathon, much like Hercules tackled his twelve labors. Instead of complaining about the challenges, I'll choose to be thankful for the obstacles and show gratitude, and reflect on all those who have left an indelible mark on my life.

From childhood dreams to Le Cirque memories ✨ Growing up, while other kids played catch with their dads, I was perfecting the art of opening wine bottles, carrying multiple plates, and deboning ducks and chickens on Sunday nights. High school was a detour into restaurants, where my true happiness lay. When college didn't quite click, my dad insisted I work only for the best in the restaurant business.

My journey led me to Sirio Maccioni's office, and I'll always regret not saving that first resume crafted on a Radio Shack Tandy computer. Sirio saw beyond the frustration and hired me as a busboy/barback at Le Cirque 2000. It was the late '90s—the golden era. The who's who of NYC society and every A-lister frequented Le Cirque, and the internet was ushering in a lavish spending spree.

The traditional French schedule was grueling—six days a week for lunch and dinner—but I cherished every moment. Weeks in, Sirio took me aside and announced my promotion to the dining room at just 19. It felt like winning the lottery. Surrounded by seasoned waitstaff, I was a kid learning to differentiate Bechamel Sauce from Hollandaise.

Ralph Hersom, the wine director, exposed me to wines worth more than my weekly earnings. Each glass had a vibrancy that fueled my passion. Nights were dedicated to Kevin Zraly's "Windows on The World" book, absorbing every drop of knowledge. Observing Sirio's room mastery and Ralph's charm, I knew I had to delve deep into the world of wine.

Today, I owe my journey to my father's insistence on working for Sirio Maccioni. Le Cirque was the turning point, shaping who I am. Gratitude to the incredible people I worked with and, most importantly, the invaluable lessons from the great Sirio Maccioni. 🍷 #LeCirqueMemories #RestaurantJourney #SirioMaccioniLegacy

11am, Sunday, November 19th: I’m a Hustla Baby Masterclass

Join us for an exciting and inspiring masterclass where you'll learn the art of hustling like a pro!

A general misconception about the wine industry is that you have to be a sommelier in a restaurant, or winemaker to be in the wine industry. However, Wine and Hip Hop cultures share an entrepreneurial spirit, not every career in wine requires a huge knowledge base to begin. So we’ve curated a dynamic group of Industry leaders from both the wine and hip-hop worlds to come together to share entrepreneurial insights and career advice.

From masters of sales like Jim Casey, Chief Sales Officer of Constellation Brands to restaurateurs like Yannick Benjamin, and social media stars like educator and influencer Katie Melchor aka @FrenchWineTutor or Dominek Tubbs @domnthecity, we're fortunate to have such a wide range of experiences to pull from. Bringing us back to Hip Hop we have Jojo Brim - Senior Vice President at 300 Entertainment / Warner Brothers Music Group.

If you are looking to break into the wine or music industry, you don't want to miss this panel!

Full Line-up:

Jojo Brim - Senior Vice President at 300 Entertainment / Warner Brothers Music Group

Katie Melchior - Wine Educator and Social Media Influencer, Wset Level 2 @FrenchWineTutor Wset 2

Yannick Benjeamin - Sommelier, co-founder of Contento Restaurant in East Harlem and Beaupierre Wines & Spirits in Hell's Kitchen.

Jim Casey - Chief Sales Officer of Constellation Brands

Dominek Tubbs - Dom N The City, Food and travel blogger and influencer

My relationship with the world of wine is a constant revolution, and it's what makes it so incredibly exciting. I always remind myself that what I know today will not be relevant tomorrow. I recently stumbled upon a quote by Dipen Parma that struck a chord with me: "The magic you're looking for is in the work you're avoiding." Every time I read this quote to myself, it blows my mind. It certainly applies to the world of wine because it's impossible to know everything. So, every time I open up a book on wine or uncork a bottle, I'm almost guaranteed to encounter something magical

Happy Birthday to my incredible wife, who has brought a love into my life that I never knew was possible. These past few years have been a wild ride, and your unwavering support has kept me afloat. Opening a restaurant and wine store amidst a pandemic was no small feat, but together, we made it happen.

As we navigate the challenges ahead, I'm reminded of Marcus Aurelius' wisdom: "What stands in the way becomes the way." Instead of letting obstacles defeat us, we'll embrace them, just as we have with everything else. In moments of self-doubt, you've been my reassuring voice, assuring me that tough times will pass. When I was sick, you provided the perfect prescription for recovery. When I teetered on the edge of giving up, you reminded me that the journey is more important than the outcome.

Not everyone is fortunate enough to experience the love you've shown me from the day we met, and that in itself is a privilege. I acknowledge that conquering my obstacles, much like Hercules, wouldn't be possible without you by my side. I'd be the most foolish person in the universe to think otherwise. Here's to us, our shared triumphs, and the love that continues to be my guiding light. 
🎉💖 #HappyBirthday

As Epictetus famously put it: “How long are you going to wait before you demand the best for yourself?”

"You could be good today, but instead, you choose tomorrow." Marcus Aurelius 

Photo Credit: @lipyanskiy_photo

Embracing the practice of "Premeditation of Adversity" has been a game-changer for me. Each morning, I engage in premeditatio malorum, contemplating potential challenges beyond my control. Life throws unexpected curveballs, like dealing with perpetually out-of-service elevators. Yet, by anticipating these hurdles and planning my response, I navigate through with resilience.

As we step into 2024, we're bound to encounter formidable obstacles—death, rejection, conflicts, and tasks we'd rather avoid. In such moments, I turn to wisdom from philosophers:

🔮 Plan tomorrow’s work today
🌟 We suffer more in imagination than in reality
🔄 Adapt to the circumstances life throws at you
🌱 Be tolerant of others, strict with yourself
🤐 Don’t be overheard complaining, not even to yourself
💭 Your opinion is your problem
🔮 The magic you seek is in the work you avoid
🎁 It’s a gift to exist, and with existence comes suffering
❤️ Love the thing you wish hadn’t happened
🧘‍♂️ Stay calm; breathe; keep pushing forward

Let's face uncertainties with a prepared mind, resilient spirit, and an unwavering commitment to growth. Here's to embracing the journey and thriving amidst the challenges. 💪✨ #NewPerspectives #2024Mindset #ResilienceJourney

Photo Credit: @lipyanskiy_photo

Reflecting on the year that has passed, I've found solace in Marcus Aurelius' wisdom: "You could be good today—instead, you choose tomorrow." Imagine treating each day like it's the 31st; perhaps anxieties would fade, and the weight of yesterday wouldn't linger into the new day.

Prepare yourself daily for challenges, contemplate new habits, and let go of those that no longer serve you. Recognize that embracing discomfort is crucial, especially as you navigate the complexities of change with age. Remember, it's not about how long you live but how well you live each day.

Take a moment to meditate. Ask yourself if you did your best, avoided complaints, embraced challenges, prioritized action over words, spoke with good purpose, and built the strongest inner citadel.

The last 121 days have been a journey for me—new challenges, moments of doubt, yet a discovery of resilience. Though the race isn't over and goals remain unfulfilled, understand that there's no true mountain top. The search is its own reward.

The disciplines I've cultivated over three years have been my compass in navigating life's choppy waters. Work with nature, be grateful for hard moments instead of complaining. Reflect on my regret about discovering ancient wisdom late but remember, I wasn't ready then. The greatest virtue that I embraced is courage. Everything that we do requires courage to overcome our fears, but if you somehow manage to build your inner citadel to overcome things that are not up to us, I believe that courage will serve you well. The courage to do something without worrying about someone else’s opinion; the courage to know that you may fail but at least you know you did it; the courage to just make something happen despite how hard it will be.

Consider the incredible odds of being born—1 in 400,000,000,000,000—yet here we are. Embrace gratitude for each day and treat it like it is your first day on earth and possibly last. 

#Reflections #SelfDiscovery #JourneyWithin

Musonius Rufus said that a man should cut the hair on his scalp the way he prunes vines by removing only what is useless and bothersome.

Today, focus is your ally, a steadfast companion on this journey you've embarked upon. As you navigate the challenges ahead, keep in mind the guiding principles you've set for yourself. The path won't be without its trials, and temptations may arise, but remember, this is the course you've chosen.

Guard against allowing external influences to disturb your peace of mind. It's not the situation itself but your judgment of it that holds the power to unsettle. Embrace simplicity by choosing silence in negative conversations and swiftly withdrawing from detrimental environments. If someone becomes the subject of unfavorable discussions, stand as their defender.

Reflect on the recent challenges faced in the past three months. Now is the time to shelve them and redirect your focus to the elements within your control. Consciously shed the habit of complaining; it stands as a stumbling block on your path to success. Engage in open conversations with your wife about troubling matters, yet be mindful of "the pause." Before speaking, assess whether your words will contribute positively to the situation.

Remember the essence of your principles:
- The Pause
- Speak only when necessary
- Refrain from complaining
- Avoid discussing yourself
- Live within your means
- Spend judiciously
- Consume mindfully
- Maintain resilience against external disturbances

Photo 📷 @heidibenzyn

Reflecting on a profound chapter from Marcus Aurelius' "Meditations" - Chapter 1: Debts & Lessons. 🌟 In this chapter, he pays homage to those who shaped him and acknowledges his privileges, expressing gratitude for nature's gifts. While few can claim an emperor's mantle, Epicteus guides us in "Reframing Impressions."

🏠 I may live in a modest Bronx apartment, yet, through reframing, it transforms into a haven with heat, warm and clean water, a bed, and a stocked fridge. Recognizing this as a life of privilege is crucial.

🤔 It's easy to compare lives, yearning for a bigger home or a desirable address. Yet, reframing impressions unveils that our lives, built with integrity, may surpass those who sacrificed integrity for success. 

🔑 Every time you unlock your door, acknowledge the privilege. Removing food from the fridge? A blessing, thanks to hardworking hands. Practice reframing to gain a powerful perspective on what truly matters.

💡 Will Guidara, in "Unreasonable Hospitality," introduces Charitable Assumption. In hospitality, taking "The Pause" when faced with challenges allows us to reframe situations. Staff or clients may act out due to personal struggles; applying empathy can shift the dynamic. 

🔄 Instead of taking things personally, consider their struggles. A passive-aggressive staff member may be dealing with personal anxieties. A challenging guest may have faced setbacks. Waiting in line for an extended period becomes more bearable when, instead of frustration, you exercise "The Pause" and assume the person cutting in has an urgent matter to attend to.

🌟 While not easy, these practices yield gratification. Overcoming challenges with a positive perspective brings fulfillment. Choose the path of reframing, empathy, and patience; the reward is immeasurable. ✨ #PerspectiveShift #Gratitude #Reflections

Amor Fati 

Picture 📸 @heidibenzyn

"No person is free who is not master of themselves." - Epictetus

Repetition stands as a cornerstone in achieving mastery, a concept the Japanese refer to as "The Shokunin," denoting an artisan who attains mastery in their craft. You might be familiar with the 10,000-hour rule, popularized by Malcolm Gladwell's "Outliers," asserting that it takes extensive practice to achieve mastery in complex skills. In a Backstage magazine interview, Anthony Hopkins revealed that he reads his scripts over 100 times, finding confidence and ease through this extensive repetition.

Enduring the relentless cycle of repetitions is challenging, yet it's this very discipline that empowers us to master not only our craft but ourselves. I've come to realize that mastery is a journey with no defined end, and therein lies its beauty. Although repeatedly reading a book may seem daunting, the depth gained from rereading surpasses the fleeting knowledge gained from a hundred books. It's a gradual process that leads to continuous self-improvement.

Consider a daily ritual of reflecting on virtues, jotting down reminders on a simple piece of paper, and carrying it with you. Incorporate quotes that inspire self-improvement and mastery:

- "One mouth; two ears"

- "Be tolerant with others and strict with yourself."

- "Procrastination is not just dishonest, it’s arrogant."

- "Your actions reveal your dedication."

- "Suffering Drives Progress."

Let these reminders guide you on the path of continuous improvement and mastery.
